body.value:
In the imperial era, particularly before the 1857 Sepoy Uprising in which Indian soldiers throughout the Indian subcontinent rebelled against British imperialists, many Britons in India (often called Anglo-Indians) partook in a number of South Asian practices, from consumption habits
 to leisure activities. British popular discourse revolved around anxieties that these Anglo-Indians were "going native."
In this plate, we see visual representations of Indian influences on the young woman, both in terms of the servants catering to her as well as the objects in the background and foreground.
